reasoning: First off, Amazon isn’t in my circle of competence. I like businesses I can understand from top to bottom – simple consumer products, insurance, railroads – not a mash-up of razor-thin retail and fast-moving cloud computing. Second, while they boast stellar operating margins (about 57%) hinting at some pricing power, their return on equity has been a mere 4.8% and ROIC under 2%, with earnings down 27% over ten periods. That’s hardly a durable economic moat. Third, management has shown discipline in limiting share issuance but pays no dividends and carries debt to equity of 1.45, which stretches the balance sheet more than I prefer. Fourth, their financial performance is inconsistent: strong segments cushion weak ones, but I look for steadiness in earnings and return. Fifth, at a market cap north of $1.6 trillion versus a conservative intrinsic value of roughly $144 billion, there’s no margin of safety – we’re paying more than double what I calculate the business is worth. Sixth, while AWS may remain a cash cow and e-commerce keeps growing, complexity and competition loom large, and I’d rather avoid businesses vulnerable to rapid tech change. Lastly, compared to the likes of Coca-Cola or See’s Candies – wonderful businesses I can hold forever – Amazon simply doesn’t meet my standards on valuation, simplicity, or predictability. In my book, that calls for a pass.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 4.8%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.5; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -27.2% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 53.5%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
